item.title: Battles rage in key Libyan city
item.description: Forces loyal to Libyan dictator Moammar Gadhafi attacked and reportedly broke through rebel lines at an opposition-held city in fighting early Saturday that killed at least 30 people, witnesses said.

item.title: Another Canadian flight set for Libya
item.description: Canada sends another military flight to try to get more Canadians out of strife-torn Libya.

item.title: Libyan army beat men to death: Calgary witness
item.description: A Calgary man who escaped from Libya says he witnessed horrific acts of brutality carried out by Libyan dictator Moammar Gadhafi's army.

item.title: Layton vows he'll be 'ready to campaign'
item.description: NDP Leader Jack Layton insists both he and his party's fortunes will be healthy enough for a federal election campaign -should one be triggered.

item.title: China budget increases social spending
item.description: The Chinese government is promising to clamp down on inflation as it raises incomes and spending on low-income housing, spreading the benefits of economic growth.

item.title: Integrity watchdog left with $534,000
item.description: MPs wants to know why Christiane Ouimet, who quit half-way through her term, received a half-million dollar severance package.

item.title: B.C. border guard gets 2 years for sex assault
item.description: A former Surrey, B.C., border guard found guilty of sexually assaulting three women while he was on duty has been sentenced to two years less a day in jail.

item.title: Ethnic voter plan is 'offensive': Liberals
item.description: The Conservatives made no apologies Friday for efforts, revealed in a misdirected letter from Immigration Minister Jason Kenney's office, to gain support in "very ethnic" communities.

item.title: Toronto 18 member gets life sentence
item.description: Shareef Abdelhaleem, a member of the so-called Toronto 18 who was convicted of participating in a bomb plot, is sentenced to life in prison with no chance of parole for 10 years.

item.title: NASA satellite crash subject of 2 probes
item.description: Investigations have been launched into why NASA's Glory satellite failed to reach orbit and crashed into the Pacific Ocean on Friday.

item.title: PMO apologizes for booting media from Ignatieff speech
item.description: The Prime Minister's Office has apologized after one of Stephen Harper's staffers hustled reporters and camera crews out of an event at the Museum of Civilization right before Liberal Leader Michael Ignatieff gave an address.

item.title: Mad cow case confirmed in Alberta
item.description: A case of mad cow disease has been found in a dairy cow in Alberta, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency confirmed to CBC News on Friday.

item.title: Alleged Tucson shooter faces more charges
item.description: The suspect in the Tucson shootings that critically wounded U.S. Rep. Gabrielle Giffords was charged on new counts that include the murders of a federal judge and a congressional aide, according to an indictment released Friday.

item.title: Baby Joseph's family gets help from 'a mama grizzly'
item.description: The parents of a terminally ill Windsor, Ont., baby are being represented by a prominent U.S. lawyer who has ties to Sarah Palin.

item.title: Dogs electrocuted, officer hurt on Toronto street
item.description: An apparent electrical malfunction has killed two dogs in Toronto's east end, critically injured a third, and sent a police officer to hospital.
